message: I am blessed to ring in the new year surrounded by my family - especially my grandkids. Happy New Year!

It’s a new year and a new Congress and it’s time for the old ways of government agencies to be updated and changed. So, I was happy to introduce a bill that would require that a short, plain language summary of any proposed rule from a government agency be made available to the American people. The American people deserve to be informed in plain language about the rules and regulations being proposed by their government; the Providing Accountability Through Transparency Act would ensure that they are.

It was an honor to be sworn in as your U.S. Representative yesterday. I feel a great sense of responsibility as your voice in Washington, D.C., and I want to thank you for the opportunity. It was a privilege to have my family with me for this joyous occasion.

My first legislative vote of the 115th Congress was to ensure that any regulations pushed through as the Obama Administration exits the door can be repealed in a timely manner.   I look forward to this bill moving quickly in the Senate and being enacted into law by the incoming Administration.

Vice President-Elect Mike Pence addressed House Republicans yesterday morning and laid out the incoming Administration's agenda for the first few days and weeks. There are going to be some exciting changes coming up soon, so stay tuned. I look forward to working with the Vice President-Elect to Make America Great Again!

I just left the House floor after proudly casting my vote to stand in solidarity with Israel.  Today's bill is in response to the current Administration’s decision to not exercise its veto on U.N. Resolution 2334 which condemns Israeli settlements and accuses our ally of violating international law. I was proud to cast my vote today to stand with Israel, in contrast to the recent position taken by our country’s representatives at the United Nations.

After the remarkable participation from the 3rd District from last year's program, I am excited to see what this year's Valentines for Veterans will bring. I hope that everyone takes a moment to create a valentine to be sent throughout the district to the men & women who have so bravely fought for the safety of our nation!

Congratulations to Missouri's newly inaugurated officials: Governor Eric Greitens, Attorney General Josh Hawley, Lieutenant Governor Mike Parson, Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft, and Treasurer Eric Schmitt. Missouri is in good  hands!

Blue lights are a traditional symbol used to recognize our law enforcement officers. Tonight, I am going to put this blue tea light candle in my window to show support for our nation's officers. Despite the daily dangers of the job, all of the men and women who wear the badge willingly face risks and strive to create safer communities for Missourians and individuals across the nation. Thank you for all that you do. #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay
NA

Very pleased to have just reintroduced legislation to designate the facility of the USPS in Pacific as the "Specialist Jeffrey L. White, Jr. Post Office."   It is my great honor to work to dedicate a Post Office in memory of Specialist White in his hometown & I will work with my colleagues in the House to ensure this bill is brought to the floor swiftly.
Looking forward to passing this important package of bills later today!

Ice and snow is making its way to the 3rd District over the next few days. Please take precaution and only drive on the roads, if necessary. Stay tuned to your local weather stations for road conditions and all of the latest updates.

Small businesses are the heart and soul of Main Street in countless towns across Missouri.   I am honored to serve on the House Small Business Committee in the 115th Congress so I can continue to help small businesses and their employees that have been buried in an avalanche of government red-tape which has hindered economic growth and expansion.

Thank you, Eric Greitens, for your leadership and information for Missourians leading up to this ice storm. Take a moment to listen to the video to find out important information for the next few days, and go to mo.gov for updates.

Obamacare has failed and the American people have spoken. It failed individuals, families, and small businesses across our state and Congress has responded to this failure by taking the first steps to repealing this broken law.   The numbers are staggering. Average annual family premiums in the employer sponsored market have increased by roughly $4,300 and now total more than $18,000 annually and individual premiums are up 27 percent. Since 2010, 80 rural hospitals have been forced to close their doors across America - and there are many more closures on the horizon. These numbers, and many more, speak for themselves.   Obamacare is a failure and is on the path to destroying health-care in America. House Republicans will not stand by and let that happen. Today's vote represents the first step in repealing this law and sets in motion the multi-step process of reforming our health-care system to make it work for all Americans.
We are less than 24 hours away from the 58th Presidential Inauguration!   Missourians, if you traveled to D.C. for the inauguration, tag me in your pictures so I can see them all.

It was an honor to be in attendance at today's 58th Presidential Inauguration. As I sat and listened to President Trump's remarks, it was impossible to not feel uplifted and ready for the new administration to get to work with Congress.
The valentines are rolling into my district offices! Keep it up, the deadline to submit a valentine to be sent to a veteran is Feb. 1 - hopefully we can break last year's record!

Proud to, once again, cosponsor the Death Tax Repeal Act. If a small business or farmer in Missouri is already struggling to make ends meet, they should not have to worry about losing the product of their hard-work due to the death of a family member.   As tax reform discussions progress, I will continue to monitor that this bill is included in any final package.

A few minutes ago, I introduced legislation to defund the United Nations' Green Climate Fund.   Just hours before the end of President Obama's term, he sent another $500 million in U.S. taxpayer dollars to the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats at the United Nations' Green Climate Fund. There has now been $1 billion in contributions over the last 10 months, however, Congress has never authorized or appropriated money for these programs.   Working with President Trump, Congress now has a real opportunity to defund these global warming programs once and for all and I look forward to finally cutting off the previous administration's frivolous slush fund.

Thanks to President Trump, the Keystone XL Pipeline will soon become a reality.   Construction of the pipeline will bring much needed jobs, reduce the dependence on foreign oil, and keep energy costs low for Missourians.

Just walked off the floor after voting in support of the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act.   Today's vote comes at a time just before thousands of Missourians make their way to Washington to advocate for the rights of the unborn. I am proud to be a voice for the unborn because all life, including the unborn, should be treated with both dignity and respect.

Today, President Trump signed three executive actions to protect our homeland.   He is directing federal funds towards a U.S.-Mexico border wall and there will be thousands of law enforcement officers deployed across our nation's southern boundary. The President is also stopping federal funds from flowing to sanctuary cities and has initiated a temporary ban on refugees and temporary visas from countries where radical Islamic terrorism is high.   I applaud President Trump for taking these actions to keep America safe.
Happening now: British Prime Minister Theresa May is addressing the House and Senate at the retreat.
I want to thank everyone attending today’s March for Life. Your dedication to protecting the life of the unborn has not gone unnoticed.
It was great meeting new people and seeing old friends at the March for Life reception. Thank you to everyone who attended!

I believe Neil Gorsuch holds the same conservative values that Americans want to see in a Supreme Court Justice. I am confident that Mr. Gorsuch has the highest regard for the United States Constitution and respects that the Supreme Court’s role is to enforce the law, not create it from the bench.

Today’s announcement is a victory for the countless individuals and families across Missouri that would have been priced out of professional financial advice under the DOL’s fiduciary rule.  I heard from constituents across the 3rd District who told me that if the fiduciary rule is implemented as currently drafted, their ability to get timely and important investment advice could make it more difficult to reach their retirement goals and provide for their later years in life. I applaud President Trump for making the decision to press pause on this this harmful rule. We should be encouraging more Americans to save for retirement, not restricting access to the tools that will help our fellow citizens achieve financial independence and security.
Happy birthday to our nation's 40th President Ronald Reagan!
NA

Earlier today, the House Small Business Committee held the first hearing of the year on the burdens that small businesses face under Obamacare. Watch my exchange with the witnesses that testified today.

This week is Thank a Farmer Week, and I would like to take time to thank the farmers and ranchers throughout Missouri’s 3rd District. With hard work and long days, America’s farmers continue to keep food prices stable while increasing production. Fun Fact: It takes longer for the average American to make enough money to pay their tax burden then it does for them earn enough to pay for a year's worth of food.

An emphasis on faith, family, and community runs deep in the 3rd District, and with that, a desire to help those in need, no matter the circumstance. Faith-based organizations provide life assistance such as job training to people in need.  These faith-based organizations are all encompassing and holistic with the assistance they provide. They not only counsel in faith, but exemplify it by their actions, preparing individuals to become self-supporting and assets to their communities. The 3rd District is stronger because of the exceptional work they provide.   Imagine if we were a country without faith. Who would provide these services?
President George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush have been together for more than seven decades. As we celebrate Valentines Day today, I wanted to showcase one of the greatest love stories.

I am pleased to announce that in the second year of the "Valentines for Veterans" program, my offices received over 13,000 valentines to be distributed to veterans around the 3rd District!  Thank you to everyone who participated in the program, your time and generosity will not go unnoticed from our men and women who have served our nation.

The House has been hard at work passing legislation to change the structure in Washington so Americans stop getting the same poor results year after year. Now, the House is committed to targeting specific regulations and stripping them from the books.

Today I received the "True Blue" award for my 100 percent voting record on pro-life legislation. Defending the unborn is not a hard decision, I believe it is our duty, as a society, to speak for those who cannot speak for themselves and allow them the right to be born into this world.

America’s rich history not only includes events such as the Civil War or when Lewis and Clark set out from St. Louis on the great expedition to explore the West – but it also includes the individuals who were our leaders during these times.  To many students throughout our country, Presidents’ Day is another day off of school. However, this federal holiday, established in 1885 in recognition of President George Washington, celebrates not only the birth of our first president, but stands as a day to celebrate all U.S. presidents past and present.  In the past, I have been asked by students in the 3rd District about who my favorite presidents are. That answer is easy: George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. Two men who selflessly navigated America through their terms and did what was right for our country and its people.  Before becoming our nation’s first president, George Washington demonstrated that he was a great leader during his time as the Commander of the Continental Army, against incredible odds that favored the British Army. General Washington never gave up, and eventually helped the United States win our independence from Great Britain. After his time as Commander of the Continental Army, in 1789 he became the first President of the United States of America under our Constitution. His leadership provided a firm foundation for our country, and he set many standards and precedents that future presidents have strived to maintain.  Then, in 1861, Abraham Lincoln was sworn in as our nation’s 16th president. President Lincoln led our country through its hardest years, the Civil War. However, in doing so, President Lincoln abolished slavery and modernized the economy. President Lincoln also gave one of our country’s most memorable presidential speeches– the Gettsyburg Address. In 272 words, and three minutes in length, President Lincoln asserted that all men are created equal and he defined the war as an effort dedicated to the principles of liberty and equality for all.  Today, Presidents’ Day isn’t just a federal holiday. Across the country, many patriotic and historical groups use February 22 as a day for celebrations and other events. Our deep American history is encouraging and so important for students to know what our country has been through. I encourage parents to tell their children what president they most admire and share their own stories about why. I hope all students continue to study and learn American history and also stay in touch with what is happening each and everyday – it is important to stay informed.
It was a great morning talking with the third graders at South Point Elementary. Their enthusiasm and eagerness to learn made the morning even better. Thank you for having me!

Today’s announcement from DHS Secretary Kelly is a commonsense decision to enforce the immigration laws of the United States, and goes a long way towards removing dangerous criminal aliens from our country.   Last year, Montgomery County and Kansas City were rocked when an illegal immigrant with a lengthy history of violence killed five individuals in Missouri and Kansas. Those actions prompted me to introduce legislation that would have forced DHS to work with and train local law enforcement to apprehend and detain criminal aliens. I am encouraged that under this guidance the Administration took a similar approach to train local law enforcement officers and give them the necessary authority to protect their communities from criminal aliens.

Thank you Vice President Pence for taking the time to come visit with hard working Missourian’s yesterday. It was an honor to have you in our state.    There’s little doubt that we have one of the most small business friendly administrations in decades. I look forward to working with the Vice President and President Donald J. Trump on rolling back the burdensome regulations that have been hurting small businesses in Missouri and across the United States.

Missourians, across the state, can take a deep breath knowing the Administration recognizes that WOTUS is an attack on individual property rights and is an encroachment on the rights of states to regulate the waters within their borders. Today’s announcement starts the process to roll this burdensome rule back and reverse the EPA’s wrongdoings from the previous Administration.

Since being sworn into office, President Trump has been fulfilling the promises he made for the last several months to the American people. Tonight, he expanded on those promises he made and the vision he wants to achieve by working with Congress. Together, we will continue to fight the most harmful aspects of the previous Administration’s work while we also work together to undo regulations, grow our economy, and help all individuals across America.

We all heard that Obamacare "means more choice, more competition, lower costs for millions of Americans." Broken promise. Insurers have left the marketplace each year since Obamacare was put into effect, leaving a third of the country, including 96 of Missouri's 114 counties, with only one provider to 'choose' from. So much for choice.   Read my op-ed with Reps. Hartzler, Smith, Long, and Wagner, and Graves by clicking the link.
The American Health Care Act is here! Get the first look at https://housegop.leadpages.co/healthcare/

It is always great to catch up with Stan Brown who represents the Paralyzed Veterans of America. We discussed many issues that veterans are facing and what Congress can do to help. Thank you for coming to the office and for all that you do!

Just walked off the House floor after voting in support of the FY17 Department of Defense Appropriations Act which passed 371-48.  This critical bill pays our troops, provides the necessary care for them and their families, and provides our men and women in uniform with the necessary tools to succeed on the battlefield. For the first time in six years, there is a 2.1 percent military pay raise for the men and women bravely defending our country. In addition, there is funding for 14 F/A-18 Super Hornets, which is important to the state of Missouri and our national security.

Great meeting with folks from Missouri Enterprise Manufacturing today - including Reggie from Union and Catie from Palmyra. They updated me on manufacturing in the state and how we can work together to strengthen it.

“Since the Affordable Care Act was passed, my wife and I have seen two major effects on our health insurance. Premiums have gone up sharply, they are now doubled what they were half a decade ago. Worse than that, our deductibles have gone up sharply.” – Stephen, Osage Beach.  The above statement from an individual in the 3rd District is just one example of the countless stories I have heard about how Obamacare has drastically impacted Americans. These stories have not fallen on deaf ears. My colleagues and I have heard from individuals, families, doctors, and small businesses to craft a replacement that will empower you, not Washington. Over the last several years, House Republicans have continued to make a promise and that is that we will not only repeal Obamacare but we will also replace it with conservative solutions that put families, doctors, and states back in charge.  Obamacare is failing, so I agree with President Trump that the American Health Care Act is a critical first step in saving our country’s health-care system. This legislation will go through as a budget reconciliation bill, which means that a minority of Senators cannot obstruct and block its consideration and passage. Next, Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price will take administrative action which will stabilize the health insurance market, increase choices, and lower costs. Lastly, Congress will advance additional legislative policies, such as allowing individuals to purchase coverage across state lines, that cannot be included in a reconciliation bill.  So, what is in this bill? I encourage everyone to go to readthebill.gop. On that website, you can find the full text of the legislation. We want everyone to have access to the American Health Care Act so you know what is in it and there are not any secrets.  First and foremost, the American Health Care Act preserves many important protections for patients and their families while making common-sense reforms to provide patients flexibility and reduced costs. This bill ensures coverage for pre-existing conditions, allows young adults to remain on their parents insurance to age 26, keeps the Medicare Part D donut hole closed, blocks federal funds from going to Planned Parenthood, and provides tax relief by getting rid of Obamacare’s worst taxes and ending the individual mandate.  The plan provides Americans access to a portable, monthly tax credit that can be used to buy a health insurance plan that is right for them – not one tied to a government mandated program. It nearly doubles the amount of money people can contribute to Health Savings Accounts and make these accounts more flexible so individuals can use it to purchase things they really need – like over-the-counter medications.  In addition, the American Health Care Act returns power to the states with the biggest entitlement reform in a generation. For the states across the country that expanded Medicaid, this bill phases out the expansion and puts the program on a budget, ending its open-ended funding and showing that entitlements can be reformed and made solvent for future generations. Missouri did not expand Medicaid, so Missourians who qualify for Medicaid will not be impacted.  In the weeks ahead, House Republicans and Congress will consider this plan through an open and transparent process. I have been to many meetings and briefings regarding the American Health Care Act and those will continue as the process moves along. I will continue to keep you informed of what is happening in Congress and if you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact my offices so they can provide additional information.

I had the opportunity to take a tour of Danuser Machine Company located in Fulton. They have over 90 employees and are currently working on an 11,000 square foot expansion. Danuser is an Original Equipment Manufacturer for over 800 customers, including John Deere. Thank you for taking the time to show me around the factory!

For the high school students participating in the 2017 Congressional Art Competition, the deadline to submit entries has been pushed back. The date is now April 21. If you have any questions, please call my Jefferson City office at 573-635-7232. Looking forward to seeing all of the artwork!

Thank you to everyone at Henderson Products, Inc., in Fulton, for showing me around the factory. At Henderson Products, they manufacture a range of equipment products such as snow plows, sand and salt spreaders, and anti-ice systems - that is just to name a few. It's no wonder they have earned the reputation as "The Dependable Ones."  UPDATE: The truck in the picture below that Henderson Products is getting ready to work on will be staying here in our own 3rd District - it's future home will be in Franklin County.

One highlight of my week was meeting with constituents in town who are with the Agriculture Leadership of Tomorrow program. We had a great discussion about ensuring that Missouri's farming and ranching tradition continues into the future.

My staff and I are wearing green today - not just for St. Patrick's Day but to spread awareness of the 1.3 million Missourians with arthritis. Thank you to the Arthritis Foundation Missouri for the t-shirt!

After years of mismanagement, it is imperative that there is proper oversight and that the Department of Veterans Affairs is held accountable for its conduct and actions. Two of the bills passed today ensure that VA employees are held accountable and that the Secretary of the VA has the ability to quickly identify staffing shortages and hire or retain high quality employees. The other House-passed bill ensures that VA bureaucrats cannot infringe upon the Second Amendment rights of our veterans. I am proud to support these common-sense, bipartisan pieces of legislation and I urge my colleagues in the Senate to bring these to the floor in a timely manner.  H.R. 1181, the Veterans Second Amendment Protection Act, would prevent VA bureaucrats from infringing upon the Second Amendment rights of our veterans, instead requiring a judicial authority to make that ruling.   H.R. 1259, the VA Accountability First Act, which would provide the VA secretary increased flexibility to remove, demote, or suspend VA employees, including Senior Executive Service Employees, for performance or misconduct.  H.R. 1367, to improve the authority of the Secretary of the VA to hire and retain physicians and other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs. This bill would improve the VA’s ability to quickly staff, recruit and retain the best and brightest individuals to ensure our veterans receive the best care.

Chuck Berry, rock 'n' roll legend and proud resident of Wentzville, paved the way for so many future musicians who took inspiration from his lyrics and sound. Let us all keep his family and friends in our thoughts during this difficult time.

Earlier today, the Office of the Inspector General released a report which outlined numerous inefficiencies within the Veterans Crisis Line.   The purpose of the Veterans Crisis Line (VCL) is to help our nation’s veterans at their most critical hour of need. Last year, after I learned that veterans were placed on hold or disconnected from the VCL, I sent a letter to the Department of Veterans Affairs demanding improvements. The response that I received from the VA indicated it was taking the necessary steps to ensure that every veteran calling into the VCL would be immediately connected with a trained professional to get the highest quality of care. Clearly that is not the case.   I will be contacting the VA regarding this most recent report and I am calling on Secretary David Shulkin to immediately make the changes necessary to ensure that our veterans receive all the help they deserve.
Happy #NationalAgDay to all of Missouri farmers, ranchers, and producers!
Watch the video below for a preview of the subcommittee hearing I will be leading this afternoon. Tune in at 1 PM CST to watch: http://financialservices.house.gov/

Today, President Trump followed through on another campaign promise – he is ushering in a new era for the American energy industry.   Over the last several years, I have heard from countless Missourians who are worried about their rising electricity bills. Today starts the process of making energy more affordable but it also means our economy will create more good paying jobs and will become more energy independent by eliminating harmful executive orders and regulations. Above all, this move will ensure that our energy policy benefits Americans families and workers.
Great having Missouri Cattlemen's Association in the office this afternoon. Always a pleasure discussing their priorities, as well as, how to #MAGA.
It was great having John Ratzenberger in the office this week. We discussed ways to get our economy moving again and the importance of keeping jobs here at home.
Happy Opening Day! Hoping for a great season from the Cardinals this year!

I’m really proud of the local communities around Missouri’s 3rd District for the help they have been providing to farmers in Kansas and Oklahoma that have been devastated by wildfires.  These local volunteers have donated and transported hundreds of bales of hay, fencing supplies, and other farm materials. Be sure to check out the article if you are interested in helping out in the wildfire relief efforts.

Today, I introduced the Protecting Life and Integrity in Research Act which will target the horrific practice of trafficking infant body parts for profit and ensure taxpayers never have to foot the bill for the endangerment of human life.  The fact that an industry has been created around the sale of aborted baby parts is deeply disturbing and that was the motivating factor to introduce this important legislation. Congress must ensure that taxpayers’ dollars are held in the highest regard when it comes to federally funded research involving fetal tissue.  For more information, read my full press release below.

It was great having Sophie Bernstein, from St. Louis, in the office today. She is a recipient of the 2017 Military Child of the Year Award for Innovation. Sophie has built, planted, and harvested 22 vegetable gardens at daycare centers and shelters around St. Louis. She has also donated more than 13,000 pounds of produce to local food banks. It was an honor to meet her and to hear all about the great things she is doing for Missouri at such a young age!

Today's hearing will serve to examine the state of the federal financial regulatory system, and to determine what can be done to increase transparency and build a strong, steady financial system and United States economy.
Yesterday, CFPB Director Cordray testified before the House Financial Services Committee. Watch my exchange with him below.
Earlier today I held a hearing to examine the state of of the federal financial regulatory system. Watch my opening statement below.

With support from members of the House of Representatives, I led a letter to the House Appropriations Committee urging the committee to include language to maintain the integrity of our nation’s medical research and provide protections for the unborn.
I hope everyone has a very happy and blessed day with loved ones and friends on this Easter Sunday.

Recently, Lincoln County received the special recognition of becoming an Agri-Ready County. This program connects counties with Missouri Farmers Care to encourage and protect agriculture across our great state. It was an honor to speak to the group and to present a letter of recognition to signify what Lincoln County has achieved.

During the Obama Administration, EPA bureaucrats in Washington often took actions that threatened Missouri families, farms, small businesses, and communities. EPA Administrator Pruitt’s visit today to listen to us about our concerns is a stark contrast to the previous eight years.   Affordable energy, good paying jobs, and property rights are top priorities for many Missourians, and after listening to Administrator Pruitt today, I am confident that we can work with him on the issues that are important to our state. I appreciate the administration’s efforts thus far to stop the Waters of the United States rule and to get the federal government’s regulatory footprint out of our local communities.

The reviews of the Orderly Liquidation Authority and the Financial Stability Oversight Council announced today are victories for American taxpayers and consumers and I applaud President Trump for his leadership on these critical matters.   As a former bank examiner, community banker, and Chairman of the Financial Institutions Subcommittee, I have long advocated for eliminating the OLA, because it puts taxpayers on the hook for bailouts, instead of putting private companies on the hook for bankruptcy. For years, I have also introduced legislation to change FSOC’s arbitrary designation processes, which lead to higher costs, fewer services, and less available credit for American consumers.   The American people deserve financial independence and I look forward to working with President Trump and my colleagues to help them achieve it.
I had the pleasure of meeting Elijah last year. He is a remarkable young man who is passionate about so many issues and a true inspiration to so many.
Thank you to Ray for all of his hard work the last few months interning in my D.C. office. Best of luck to you in your final year at Mizzou in the fall!

This week I introduced legislation that would reform the Endangered Species Act.   In the 44 years since the ESA was first enacted into law, thousands of species have been listed as threatened or endangered, yet less than 30 have been recovered and delisted. This legislation will bring transparency to the listing process and increase recovery of species, while protecting the rights of states and private property owners. I want to thank Senators Rand Paul (KY) and Dean Heller (NV) for championing this legislation in the United States Senate.   It is my hope we can educate our colleagues about this common-sense legislation and bring it to the House floor quickly.
Dodd-Frank has failed, but there is a better way - the Financial CHOICE Act.

I want to thank all of the first responders who are hard at work helping families across Missouri with the recent storms.   Water levels are expected to be well above flood stage along many rivers throughout Missouri in the coming days, including the Meramec, Maries, Gasconade, Osage, Missouri, and Mississippi.   Please pay attention to your surroundings, don't drive through standing water, and stay alert if you live in a flash flood prone area. Go to https://www.mo.gov/stopfloodingdeaths/ for information on what to do in flash floods, and go to http://traveler.modot.org/map/ to stay up to date on road closures.

Water levels are still rising throughout Missouri due to the recent storms. Use the links below to keep track of your local flood conditions in Missouri’s 3rd District. Please pay attention to your surroundings, don't drive through standing water, and stay alert if you live in a flood prone area.  General Flood Preparedness: https://www.mo.gov/stopfloodingdeaths/  Statewide Road Closures: http://traveler.modot.org/map/  Osage County: https://www.facebook.com/EOC911/  Maries County: https://www.facebook.com/Mariescountyemergencymanagement/  Gasconade County: https://www.facebook.com/Gasconade-County-E-911-128132757367910/?ref=br_rs  Franklin County: https://www.facebook.com/fcemamo/  Callaway County: https://www.facebook.com/CallawayCountySO/?ref=br_rs  Jefferson County: https://www.facebook.com/jeffcooem/  St. Charles County: https://www.facebook.com/StCharlesCountyMo/?hc_ref=SEARCH&fref=nf  Warren County: https://www.facebook.com/Warren-County-Emergency-Services-911-Center-255688691115258/  Montgomery County: https://www.facebook.com/dispatch.montgomery.mo/?ref=br_rs  Cole County: https://www.facebook.com/ColeCounty/  Camden County: https://www.facebook.com/EMA65020/ Miller County: https://www.facebook.com/MCE911/  Lincoln County: https://www.facebook.com/LincolnCountyEMA/

In the last few days, flooding has devastated Missouri and other Midwestern states. It’s a reminder that the threat of flooding is real and constant. The aftermath of these floods will likely remind us that the National Flood Insurance Program is in need of serious reform.   My Taxpayer Exposure Mitigation Act takes steps to build a safer system that will better serve taxpayers and policyholders alike. Homeowners and businesses across the country depend on the accuracy of flood maps in making decisions about flood insurance and flooding risks. It’s time to make sure the program is on sounder financial footing, that taxpayers are protected from footing the bill for future losses, and it’s time to shift power from bureaucrats in Washington to states, local communities and policyholders.   This bill is an important step towards meaningful reform of the National Flood Insurance Program, and I look forward to working with my colleagues on these and other reform initiatives.

I want to salute all of the small businesses and their employees as we recognize Small Business Week which is April 30-May 6.   Without a doubt the motivation, dedication, and drive from owners and employees of small businesses are at the heart of growth and prosperity in the U.S. economy. I will continue to be a champion of small businesses and support policies that enhance opportunities for entrepreneurs by ensuring they are set up for success, rather than failure.

Obamacare cannot be fixed, but our nation’s health-care can. The American Health Care Act came together in an effort to give all Americans more choices, more control, and more affordable health-care. The American Health Care Act will deliver better long-term results and, during the interim, there will be an effective transition. After seven years of a law that saw premiums rise and individuals lose doctors that they liked, it is past time to repeal and replace this failing law with one that brings down costs, is personalized, and works for everyone.
In the same vote series, I voted to ensure that no members of Congress and staff are exempt from the American Health Care Act.
A great article by my friend and colleague in the House of Representatives.

After dozens of pieces of artwork were submitted to my office, Heather Mote of Iberia has been named the winner of the 2017 Congressional Art Competition.   Heather, a freshman at Iberia High School, used charcoal to create the winning artwork titled “Courageous.” Heather will have her work displayed along with other winners from congressional districts across the country in the Cannon Tunnel in the United States Capitol.    Having the opportunity to call Heather and tell her that it was her artwork that ultimately won this year’s Congressional Art Competition is a conversation I will not forget. She was surprised and genuinely overcome with excitement about the opportunity that she has received. I look forward to meeting her when she comes to Washington this summer and she can proudly show off her artwork to everyone who walks the halls of the United States Capitol each and every day. I want to thank all of the participants for another successful year of the art competition.  The first runner-up was Kate Williams, a senior from Washington High School with the artwork entitled “Love Always, Your Jack.” Ashley Jones, a sophomore at North Callaway High School, was the second runner-up with the artwork entitled “Sunrise in D.C.” The third runner-up was Alexis Martin, a senior at Warrenton High School. Her artwork is entitled “Aesthete.”
Great discussion this morning. Thank you for having me!

I would like to encourage the many outstanding young men and women throughout the 3rd District to learn about the military academy admissions process. It’s an opportunity to gain a strong college education and to serve our country. For those selected from the competitive field of qualified students from across the country, it’s a positive, life-changing experience.  The four United States service academies accepting Congressional nominations are West Point in New York (Army), the U.S. Naval Academy in Maryland (Navy and Marine Corps), the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado (Air Force), and the Merchant Marine Academy in New York (Merchant Marine). The U.S. Coast Guard Academy does not accept Congressional nominations, but my office can provide information about it.  Students can contact my Jefferson City office for information about the academy process.
I want to wish a very Happy Mother's Day to all of the moms in our lives!
Thank you to all of the men and women in blue who tirelessly work to keep us safe and let's honor those who gave their lives in the line of duty. #PoliceWeek

A big congratulations to the high school students at Festus High School who won the Team American Rocketry Challenge this past weekend. They defeated the top 100 teams from across the country to win the world's largest rocket contest.   Festus High School's team competed against the 100 other teams and had to launch two rockets: the first launch was a two stage rocket, launch to 775 feet, launch and land safely within 41 to 43 seconds, and not break the raw egg within the rocket. The second launch had to go to 800 feet in 42 to 44 seconds without cracking a raw egg.   The team will now represent the United States at the International Air Show in Paris. You have made Missouri proud and we will be rooting you on in June!

Later this week, the House Ways and Means Committee is holding a hearing on tax reform and will detail what pro-growth tax reform looks like.   We must simplify the code, bring down rates, and increase competitiveness by leveling the playing field for American businesses.   I encourage you to watch the hearing which will be held on Thursday at 9 a.m. CST.

Earlier this year, hth companies was honored with the 2016 Contractor of the Year award. hth companies, was founded in Union in 1984. This is an incredible honor and I want to congratulate the company on a remarkable achievement.
Excellent article. Winston Churchill’s words still resonates today - that America must not grow complacent and must maintain our moral leadership in the world.

It was a pleasure meeting and spending time with Sue Engelage while she was in Washington for National Youth Foster Shadow Day. Sue is a bright, young individual who is passionate about advocating for foster kids, not only in Missouri, but across America. As a member of Congress, I remain committed to ensuring that every child has a safe, supportive, and permanent family.   Sue lives in Lohman and is now the Program Coordinator for Central Missouri Foster Care and Adoption Association.

My colleagues and I in the Missouri delegation just sent President Trump a letter urging that he approve Governor Greitens' request for a major disaster declaration after the State suffered severe flooding earlier this year.

The other evening, I was honored to be a guest at the U.S. Army Twilight Tattoo in Arlington, Virginia. Twilight Tattoo is a live military pageant that features soldiers from the 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment, also known as "The Old Guard" and the U.S. Army Band "Pershing's Own." During the hour long event, we got a glimpse into American history through performances by U.S. Army bands, vocalists, and the drill team. During the event, I thought about our nation's military veterans and active duty personnel and unless you have walked in their boots, it is difficult to fully understand their experiences and what they have been through. It was a gentle reminder, and humbling experience, that we owe so much to these individuals for their service. What made this event even more special is that Montgomery County Middle School performed for the audience. There were 45 students who participated and it was great to see Missouri represented so well at this wonderful military pageant.
Operation Choke Point must come to an end once and for all. I introduced legislation that would make that a reality.

The recently released video of Planned Parenthood physicians discussing dismemberment abortions is appalling and we cannot sit by and continue to let these actions continue.  Following the conclusion of the House and Senate investigations into fetal tissue trafficking, numerous abortion providers and procurement businesses were referred to the Department of Justice and Federal Bureau of Investigation, as well as state authorities, for criminal review.   However, more action is needed. Earlier this year, I introduced the Protecting Life and Integrity in Research Act which targets the horrific practice of trafficking infant body parts for profit and ensures taxpayers never have to foot the bill for the endangerment of human life. I will continue to push for this important legislation to make it to the House floor immediately.

I welcome President Trump’s announcement to withdraw the United States from the Paris Climate Change Agreement.   The Paris Agreement was just another example of the Obama Administration circumventing Congress to push a politically driven agenda at the expense of American workers and taxpayers. Earlier this year, I reintroduced legislation, the No Tax Dollars for the United Nations’ Climate Agenda Act, that would prevent any taxpayer dollars from being used to the fund the United Nation’s International Panel on Climate Change, Framework Convention on Climate Change, the Green Climate Fund, or any of the Climate Investment Funds. These slush funds have cost American taxpayers over $1 billion under the Obama administration.   Thankfully, under President Trump, we have already been able to pass a government funding bill to prevent this egregious abuse of taxpayer dollars. I look forward to working with the Trump Administration to make this prohibition permanent.

On Friday, President Trump issued a Major Disaster Declaration for the state of Missouri, triggering the release of federal funds to help communities across the state recover from the severe storms and flooding that occurred earlier this spring.   President Trump's announcement is the first step in helping our communities heal. The torrential rainfall that swept across Missouri in April and May exhausted the resources of our state. Federal funding is vital to helping thousands of Missourians recover.  The President issued Stafford Act assistance for individuals and households in the following 3rd District Counties: Franklin, Gasconade, Jefferson, Maries, and Osage.  The President issued Stafford Act assistance for emergency work and the repair or replacement of disaster-damaged facilities in the following 3rd District Counties: Camden, Cole, Franklin, Gasconade, Jefferson, Maries, Miller and Osage.  All areas in Missouri are eligible for assistance under the Hazard Mitigation Grant Program.  If you have been affected by the storms and flooding, you can apply for assistance at www.DisasterAssistance.gov<http://www.DisasterAssistance.gov>. You can also call the registration phone number at 1-800-621-3362; those who have a speech disability or hearing loss and use TTY, should call 1-800-462-7585 directly; for those who use 711 or Video Relay Service (VRS), call 1-800-621-3362.

Each year, there are fewer and fewer of the brave souls who stormed the beaches on June 6, 1944, and that is why it is critical that we continue to commemorate their efforts and sacrifices that helped free this world of one of the greatest evils our world has ever known.  I encourage all Americans to take a moment to remember those who fought and died that day.
Earlier today the House Committee on Financial Services held a hearing on the need for reform of the National Flood Insurance Program. Watch my exchange with those that testified below.

I am encouraged to hear President Trump highlight the need to invest in the nation’s water infrastructure which is so critical to Missouri and the 3rd District.   According to the U.S. Census Bureau Trade Data, in 2015, 72 percent of United States agricultural exports and 71 percent of imports were waterborne. With much of the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers in the 3rd District, I know just how important it is to invest and care for our inland waterways. Investment in our water infrastructure system is vital and I am encouraged to work with the President and the administration to ensure America continues to lead the country in feeding the world.
The Financial CHOICE Act offers a responsible approach to financial regulation that will protect consumers and allow the American economy to flourish.

Today represents a major victory for Main Street America and Americans who simply want the opportunity to achieve financial independence.   Passage of the Financial CHOICE Act will end the era of taxpayer-funded bailouts for Wall Street and give Main Street access to the financial tools it needs to succeed. The Financial CHOICE Act delivers much needed regulatory relief, and I am proud of my colleagues in the House of Representatives who recognize the importance of this comprehensive, jobs first, bill.

It was great having Small Business Administrator Linda McMahon in the office today. We discussed how we can work together to empower our nation's small businesses and community banks so they can grow and succeed.

My staff and I are safe. Please pray for my friend Steve Scalise, staffers, and Capitol Police who were injured this morning.   It is because of the remarkable response from our nation’s Capitol Police that kept this horrible event from being even worse. Their heroism saved so many lives.

Each year on June 14, we pause and recognize the day as Flag Day to celebrate and honor our American flag. While we all know the American flag is the symbol of our freedom and our national pride and the history behind Flag Day is important to know and understand.  On June 14, 1777, a resolution from the Second Continental Congress called for an official United States flag. The resolution called for the flag to “be thirteen stripes, alternate red and white; that the union be thirteen stars, white in a blue field, representing a new constellation.” Then in 1916, President Woodrow Wilson wrote: “I therefore suggest and request that throughout the nation and if possible in every community the fourteenth day of June be observed as Flag Day with special patriotic exercises.” And in 1949, President Harry S. Truman signed Flag Day’s permanent observance into law.  The “Stars and Stripes” symbolize our freedom and strength, as well as the American spirit that others around the world have come to know and respect. Many of our fellow Americans have made tremendous sacrifices to preserve all that our American flag represents.  In the House of Representatives, there is a congressional flag program which individuals in the 3rd District can request a flag that has been flown over the United States Capitol. Each year, my office receives dozens of rquests from Eagle Scouts, veterans, individuals retiring or celebrating an anniversary and would like a flag to hang outside their home or keep inside. The price of the flag depends on the size and material. If you are interested in having a flag flown over the Capitol or if you have any questions, please call my Washington, D.C. office for more information. My staff would be happy to help.  I encourage you to take a moment and reflect on what the American flag means to you and to those who defended our country over the last hundreds of years.

There has been a lot of confusion over where Missouri stands when it comes to the federal REAL ID standards, so I wanted to provide you with a quick update.   On June 12th Missouri’s Governor, Eric Greitens signed a bill into law that would require the Department of Revenue to issue REAL ID compliant drivers licenses. This new law will give Missourian’s the choice of a REAL ID compliant license or a non-compliant license.   It may take up to two years for the Department of Revenue to complete the process to become REAL ID compliant. This is why my Missouri congressional colleagues and I have requested a waiver from DHS, like the waivers granted in 27 other states. That letter is attached below.   If our request is granted, Missourian’s will continue to be allowed on military bases and flights without additional forms of identification. The Missouri Department of Revenue will notify the public when they can receive REAL ID compliant identification.
My bills to reform NFIP just passed in the House Committee on Financial Services. They include much needed reforms to protect taxpayers.

Career and technical education programs are so important for individuals throughout Missouri because they help high school and community college students attain the hands-on experience they need for jobs in a broad range of industries.   Today's legislation will empower state and local community leaders with the resources and flexibility they need to build community partnerships and foster educational engagement with employers. Programs in the 3rd District particularly will benefit by the increase in the percentage of federal funds states can set aside to assist students in rural areas. I am pleased this bipartisan legislation passed in the House and I hope the Senate brings this important bill up for debate in the near future.

Today is a victory for religious freedom. Just moments ago, Supreme Court ruled in favor that Trinity Lutheran Church in Columbia has the same right as charitable groups to seek money for new playground surfaces and other needs.   This decision means that the government cannot discriminate against religious organizations and exclude them from receiving a generally available public benefit simply because they are religious. I have closely monitored this case and I signed an amicus brief with several of my Missouri colleagues to ensure the First and Fourteenth Amendments are not violated.

Exciting news from Festus High School. On Friday, the Festus High School Rocket Club won first place at the International Paris Air Show.   The team represented the United States and competed against other teams from the United Kingdom, France, and Japan.   Congratulations to these bright, young students who have made Missouri, and America, incredibly proud by bringing home a first place win at the International Rocketry Challenge!

I am pleased to announce that several high school students in the 3rd District have accepted offers of appointments to the U.S. Naval Academy and the U.S. Air Force Academy.   The young men and women who have been selected to these two academies have shown exemplary talent and leadership and they are very deserving of this achievement. I want to congratulate these individuals on all of their hard-work and I wish them the very best in each of their bright futures. Today is a victory for Missourians - especially for farmers, ranchers, and small businesses across the state.   The Trump administration announced a proposed rule to repeal the Waters of the U.S. rule which is a huge step in the right direction in returning power back to the states and providing regulatory certainty to our nation's farmers. The Waters of the U.S. rule represented the largest land grab in American history, and was one of the most egregious regulations stemming from the Obama administration. I applaud the President and EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt by reversing the EPA's wrongdoings from the previous administration.

It was an honor to welcome Heather Mote, winner of the Congressional Art Competition, to Washington today.   Today serves as an opportunity to allow each of the art competition winners to visit our nation's capitol and be recognized for their achievements. I truly enjoyed meeting Heather and I wish her all of the best in the future!

With Fourth of July celebrations happening all across the 3rd District, I wanted to provide an opportunity for you to share pictures of your festivities with me. If you have a great picture of hamburgers on the grill or fireworks in the sky, send me a Facebook message with your pictures and I will post them and tag you in it for everyone to enjoy!  I hope everyone has a lot of fun over the long weekend with family and friends. It is important to remember that our country is special and that its independence should always be a cause for celebration. I'm looking forward to seeing the pictures from all over our great district!

As we fire up our grills and don ourselves in red, white, and blue - let us always remember what we are celebrating. We are celebrating and reflecting on the many rights and freedoms that we enjoy in the greatest nation and the struggles to gain and protect them.   On behalf of myself, my family, and my staff - I hope everyone has a safe and wonderful Fourth of July!
Here are some of the Independence Day pictures we received from constituents across the 3rd District. It looks like everyone had a lot of great food and fun!

The economy has stabilized and is starting to improve. Today’s job numbers look great! More jobs were added than expected, more people joined the work force, and wages improved. As we get more pro-employment and business legislation through Congress I believe we will see wages and the economy improve at a greater pace.

Good news: the United States Postal Service recently announced it will relocate its current Wentzville facility to a new facility on Luetkenhaus Blvd.   After months of working with city officials in Wentzville, I am incredibly pleased to see USPS has recognized the need for a new facility that will benefit the city as it continues to grow.   The USPS will continue to provide services at its current location until the new facility is open. The new location is expected to open in 2018.

Update: After my colleagues and I in the delegation sent a letter to the Department of Homeland Security last month, we just found out the agency has granted Missouri an extension to allow the state additional time to meet the requirements of REAL ID.   This extension will now allow Missouri ID's to be used to enter federal facilities and military bases. I will keep you updated as more information regarding REAL ID is released.

Last year, Missouri was rocked when an illegal alien, Pablo Serrano-Vitorino, killed a man in Montgomery County and four other individuals in Kansas City, Kansas. It is infuriating that Immigration and Customs Enforcement didn't follow proper procedures and that federal immigration authorities twice missed opportunities to detain Serrano-Vitorino.   In response to this, I had introduced a bill that would empower local law enforcement to make federal immigration actions - so they can stop this senseless crime from happening again. Also, the House continues to fight to get criminal illegal aliens off our streets by recently passing Kate's Law and the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act.  http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/07/10/lawsuit-ice-negligent-in-case-man-charged-in-5-killings.html
It was great having a fellow mid-Missourian in the office today. Thank you Rod Smith for stopping by and bringing your family!

I just walked off the House floor after casting my vote in support of the National Defense Authorization Act.   The men and women who defend our freedoms are our country's most valuable asset. As a Member of Congress, I have a responsibility to provide these men and women with the equipment and supplies that improve their capabilities on the battlefield and keep them safe.   This legislation provides for 22 F/A-18 Super Hornets that are assembled in Missouri and fully funds the 2.4 percent pay raise guaranteed to our men and women in uniform under current law.   Our troops sacrifice so much for our country and are the greatest fighting force on this planet. This bill provides them with the tools and equipment that match their skill and proficiency.

Human trafficking has had a horrible impact on families all over the State of Missouri and the rest of our country. This is why I was happy to join my House colleagues last week in passing 3 major bipartisan bills that aim to help the victims of human trafficking, aid law enforcement, prevent trafficking, and punish the traffickers. If you have the time and are interested in learning more about human trafficking, its effects right here in Missouri, and why this legislation is needed, I highly recommend the documentary    .
